title: Alesha MacPhail's evil killer was at school talk on child abduction before murder
text:

Alesha MacPhail's evil killer was given a school talk on child abduction just years before he raped and murdered the six-year-old.

Aaron Campbell was amongst the pupils sat in an assembly as they were taught about the impact the loss of a child can have.

Just three years later, he would take Alesha from her bed on the Isle of Bute before carrying out his twisted attack and leaving her body in the woods.

Charity founder Sandra Brown told the Daily Record of her horror at finding out Campbell was in the audience when she gave the talk.

Sandra, who works with the Moira Anderson Foundation, has now spoken about the chilling discovery.

She said: “I was shocked last year when I discovered that in the hall that day was Aaron ­Campbell, who would only have been around 13.

“How anyone so young could hear about the heartbreak sexual ­predators can cause and the devastation for families left without their child then go out and do what he did is utterly incomprehensible.”

The Moira Anderson Foundation supports families affected by child sexual abuse.

It was founded by Sandra, who accused her own father - a convicted child rapist - of the abduction of Moira, aged 11.

(Image: Daily Record)

The charity, which has its 20th anniversary in February, has supported more than 3600 people referred to it and has developed educational packages for schools.

In summer 2015, Sandra told an assembly of pupils at Rothesay Academy, on the Isle of Bute, about her memories of Moira’s ­disappearance in 1957.

Three years later, Campbell, 16, murdered Alesha, six.

Sandra said: “I wanted to ensure all the children present heard about the services we provide and I also described to them the dreadful impact on a community when a child disappears.

“Moira’s parents, I told them, were the ones who served the life sentence and not my father who was ­responsible for her abduction, and, I believe, her murder.

“I can still feel the shocked silence in that hall. But it was my turn to be shocked when I learned that Campbell had been there.”

Alesha, from Airdrie, was only a few days into a family holiday in Rothesay when Campbell took her from her bed on July 2 last year.

(Image: Daily Record)

Her body was found the next morning. A ­post-mortem revealed she had suffered 117 injuries.

Campbell was found guilty at trial, and then confessed to the killing before being given a life sentence.

Moira’s disappearance, had a profound effect on Sandra.

Unknown to Sandra at the time, her own dad, bus driver ­Alexander Gartshore, had been charged with raping the family’s babysitter, 13.

He was jailed for the rape just a few weeks after Moira vanished and even though he was driving the bus on which Moira was last seen, he was not questioned about her disappearance at the time.

As an adult, Sandra researched the disappearance – her body has never been found – and learned more about her father’s predatory attraction to girls.

In 1998, she published a book, Where There is Evil, accusing her father, then still alive, of the crime.

(Image: PA)

She used proceeds from the book sales to set up the ­foundation in Moira’s name, and in a private capacity, has worked closely with the police and academics to try to recover Moira’s remains.

Gartshore died, aged 85, in a Leeds hospital in April 2006 never having been charged in relation to Moira, but the Crown Office has since said he should have been ­prosecuted for her murder.

She said: “The past 20 years have been a ­rollercoaster but we are so proud of what the charity has achieved. It’s been a massive part in the lives of ­thousands of families going through the very worst thing they could have imagined.

As well as supporting them, we have tried to educate children and give them the ­confidence to keep themselves safe, teaching them about what is safe and what isn’t, and about the importance of telling when someone makes them uncomfortable.

“Those of us who have delivered that message to schools have seen children taking it all in, and we think we have empowered them.

"But it was devastating to learn that the message failed to have any effect on one young boy, who went on to commit a most horrific crime.”
description: Charity founder Sandra Brown said she had no idea monster Aaron Campbell was in the audience when she gave the talk on the Isle of Bute in Scotland
